title: How "Deep Content" Will Protect Your SEO in the AI Era
description: If you want to thrive in search in a post-AI world, publish more "deep content."
content: Joshua Hardwick Head of Content @ Ahrefs (or, in plain English, I'm the guy responsible for ensuring that every blog post we publish is EPIC). Get the week's best marketing content Email Subscription Subscribe Leave this field empty if you're human: Contents SEOs are panicking that AI is taking over and their jobs are done. But Iâ€™m uncharacteristically optimistic this isnâ€™t the case.Yes, AI has changed SEO forever (and will continue to do so), but itâ€™s not going to kill it. We just need to adapt. How? By prioritizing â€œdeep contentâ€ about topics that canâ€™t be answered quickly or easily.Here are three reasons why I think this is the future of SEO.ContentsDeep content answers questions AI canâ€™t answerIf you ask ChatGPT how to reinstall macOS, you can easily follow its instructions to get the job done. It clearly explains what you need to do and how to do it.This is the kind of â€œshallowâ€ topic that AI is coming for.Once Google rolls out SGE to the masses (which will probably happen soon), searchers wonâ€™t need to click for answers to these kinds of questions. Theyâ€™ll be right there in the search results courtesy of AI. The robots will steal the traffic.Compare this to ChatGPTâ€™s answer for a topic like how to run a content audit:Even with half the answer cut off, the issue is clear: it tells us what to do but not how to do it.How do we choose the right objective?How do we pull data from Google Analytics, our CMS, and website crawlers to compile a content inventory?Which are the â€œappropriate toolsâ€ that will help with the audit?Because this is a deeper topic, it needs a deeper answer. You canâ€™t get that from AI. You need to click a result to find a tutorial from someone with actual experience performing content audits.These are the kinds of topics you should be prioritizing in an AI world.How can you find â€œdeepâ€ topics?Thereâ€™s no exact science. Itâ€™s largely about knowing your industry well and applying common sense. However, if youâ€™re doing keyword research, you can narrow things down by excluding keywords that trigger featured snippets. After all, if Google thinks a query can already be answered well with a featured snippet, an AI answer will definitely do the job.You can do this in Keywords Explorer with the SERP features filter:You can also use the â€œIdentify intentâ€ button in Keywords Explorer to learn more about what searchers are looking for. If it seems like something that couldnâ€™t be answered quickly or easily, itâ€™s probably a â€œdeepâ€ topic.For example, it tells us that many of the people searching for â€œcontent auditâ€ want â€œa detailed process for conducting a content audit, including templatesâ€:Itâ€™s going to be virtually impossible for generative AI to give searchers thisâ€”especially the templates.If youâ€™re still not sure whether a topic is â€œdeepâ€ enough for AI to fail, paste your topic into ChatGPT or Gemini and see what it generates. If it leaves much to be desired and only tells you the what, not the how, then itâ€™s probably a deep topic.Deep content earns more backlinksBacklinks are still a ranking factor. AI hasnâ€™t changed that. You need to earn them if you want to rank for anything competitive, and the best way to do that is to showcase unique experiences, expertise, and data in your content.For example, we got a link from adobe.com (DR 96) when they cited a statistic from our study on how many pages get no search traffic:And we got a link from hubspot.com (DR 93) when they cited the SEO report template we made:But hereâ€™s the problem:Itâ€™s hard to do this for shallow topics because thereâ€™s not much you can add. For example, take the topic of how to reinstall macOS. What exactly can you write here beyond the same basic instructions featured in every other post? Nothing. Itâ€™s virtually impossible to make â€œlinkableâ€ content about this topic. Itâ€™s too shallow.Itâ€™s hard to rank for shallow topics because your content is never unique. Itâ€™s just a bunch of words that have already been said a million times. Thereâ€™s nothing underneath the surface for people to cite and link to.Itâ€™s whatâ€™s below the surface of your content that earns backlinks!Deep content is interestingâ€¦ and thatâ€™s what Google wantsItâ€™s hard to make shallow topics interesting. I think thatâ€™s why thereâ€™s so much dull â€œSEO contentâ€ out there. You know the kind of stuff Iâ€™m talking about: no personality, just vague answers to boring questions nested under keyword-rich H2s.Now, I know what youâ€™re probably thinking:â€œBut Josh, this is what works! Weâ€™re only doing it because itâ€™s what Google wants!â€That might be true for shallow topics, but we already discussed how AI will steal the traffic from these in the not-so-distant future. For deep topics that require more explanation, your content needs to be engaging and interesting.There are (at least) two reasons for this.Interesting content = â€œinformation gainâ€Even if bringing something new and interesting to the table doesnâ€™t earn you more backlinks, it may still help you rank higher in Google.Thatâ€™s because Google cares about the originality of content and almost certainly has mechanisms in place to identify and reward it. They even patented a mechanism for scoring â€œinformation gainâ€ back in 2022.Engaging content = better user signalsIf you want to spark debate among SEOs, steer the conversation towards user signals.Many in the industry have been convinced for years that user signals like click-through rate are ranking signals. You might even be familiar with Rand Fishkinâ€™s infamous mini-experiment from 2014 where he asked his Twitter followers to click on a search result en masse, leading to a #1 ranking that evening.Care to help with a Google theory/test? Could you search for â€œIMEC Labâ€ in Google & click the link from my blog? I have a hunch.â€” Rand Fishkin (follow @randderuiter on Threads) (@randfish) May 1, 2014 Google says signals like these arenâ€™t ranking factors because theyâ€™re too noisy.If you think about it, clicks in general are incredibly noisy. People do weird things on the search result pages. They click around like crazy, and in general itâ€™s really, really hard to clean up that data.Gary Illyes, Webmaster Trends Analyst GoogleButâ€¦ they also say this on their â€œHow Search Worksâ€ page:We also use aggregated and anonymised interaction data to assess whether Search results are relevant to queries. We transform that data into signals that help our machine-learned systems better estimate relevance.Tomayto, tomahto. Directly or indirectly, user data influences Googleâ€™s algorithms. If all youâ€™re publishing is dull, uninspiring content that AI could write in a heartbeat, nobody is going to read or engage with it. This might negatively impact your ability to rank.Final thoughtsIf you want the ChatGPT-esque summary of this post, itâ€™s this: prioritize deep topics that AI will struggle to answer and create interesting and engaging content about them. Thatâ€™s how you build an SEO moat in an AI world.I know that can seem like a waste of time, especially in a world of ever-decreasing attention spans. Itâ€™s easy to convince yourself that dull AI answers are what people actually want.This is exactly how I felt a few months agoâ€¦ before Tim kindly set me straight ğŸ˜…Maybe itâ€™s just because heâ€™s my boss and I respect him, but I think thereâ€™s some real truth to this comment. People still want to read content, but only if itâ€™s engaging and deep.So, letâ€™s make it our collective mission to pick wiser battles and craft interesting content that stands the test of time.
